Award.AwardTitle: BPC-DP: A Multi-tiered Mentoring Model (M3) for Increasing Minority and Women Participation in Computing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Alabama proposes a multi-tiered mentoring model (M3) that partners a diverse university campus with a large urban school system. The project will provide high-level instruction in computational thinking across three different age groups using a "Learn to Teach, Teach to Learn" approach. The participants will include: (1) middle and high school students from minority backgrounds, (2) their teachers, (3) minority and majority college students with secondary science education or computer science majors, (4) University educators from four interdisciplinary units (Computer Science, and the schools of Education, Engineering, and Medicine); and (5) a learning design firm dedicated to enhancing computing education through media and technology.

The Specific Aims of M3 are: (1) to recruit a cadre of minority and women middle and high school students into the computing pipeline by presenting engaging mentored technology experiences, (2) to expose pre-service secondary education students to pedagogical and technical aspects of computing education, through interdisciplinary peer mentorship, (3) to extend computational expertise among high school teachers in predominantly minority schools to encourage them to actively learn and teach computer science courses in their schools, (4) to increase the retention of minority students in undergraduate computer science programs by providing them opportunities to create innovative tools for computing education, (5) to engage K-12 administrators and parents of participants through workshops that highlight the benefits of careers in computing and (6) to evaluate the effects of M3 on student and teacher performance in computing education, their aptitude and interest for this area of research and tracking of career choices among participants.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Computer Science (CS) is a rapidly changing area, in which it is difficult for anyone to stay fully current. Further, minorities and women are poorly represented in CS careers. Many studies have shown that near-peer education is an effective method to facilitate standard modes of education used in the classroom and engage underrepresented students in CS. With these findings in mind, we developed a program in which CS education could be empowered by older students (including many from underrepresented groups) passing on knowledge to younger students, thus providing for an inexpensive and knowledgeable adjunct to traditional classroom education. M3 (Multiple Mentoring Model) was created to test this addition to education in which knowledge is disseminated not only by teachers, but also by students who are about 4 years senior to the students being taught. Thus, college CS and Education majors were trained initially in the Alice programing language and provided with training in pedagogy and classroom management during a semester long course. The following spring, the college students were sent out to teach Alice in regularly scheduled classes in area high schools in which over 90% of the students were minority and over 75% were “high needs.” M3 was integrated into regular math or computer applications courses, the latter of which primarily consisted of students learning to use “canned” programs (e.g., MS Office). The students were initially taught to use Alice to develop video games or videos. In so doing, the students learned to appreciate the key principles that are necessary for all computer languages, e.g., sequence, loops and conditionals. After the high school students learned Alice, they were sent to area underserved Middle Schools to facilitate 1-week long summer camps in Alice under the leadership of their college mentors. This allowed for a multiplying effect in which 10 trained college students could provide for education of 60 high school students who could then provide mentoring to 120-180 middle school students. Finally, at both the high and middle school level, parents were encourage to attend closing ceremonies and learn about what their children had learned about the potential career option sin CS. Many of the parents had little knowledge of the promise of such careers prior to these sessions.

Although the initial interactions of M3 worked relatively well, we quickly realized two challenges. First, the near-peer relationship often became too near and occasionally turned romantic if the age difference was too close (e.g., a grade 9 mentor assisting with a middle school camp). To avoid this, we tried to populate the successive year classes with older high school students and 6th grade middle school students. Further, we increased our classroom management training of the college mentors and high school students. A second problem was engagement of the high school students. Although the students seemed to like Alice as a programming language, about 40% seemed less than optimally engaged, at least initially. Also, many of the students did not see an opportunity to take Alice to a competitive level. In the last 3 years of the program, we transitioned to start the high school class (first 6 of 16 weeks) with robotics, teaching the basic principles of computing through this platform. The ability of the students to physically manipulate and see their project in 3D seemed to engage more of the students early, especially the boys. It also provided a platform for students to compete with their new found skills. In the last three years, teams from the M3 schools made up of students with little previous CS training, competed in the state-wide Alabama Robotics Competition at the University of Alabama.
